title: How to Remove Stickers from Glossy Paperback Book Covers

steps.headline: Dip a cotton ball in a bottle of 91% rubbing alcohol.
steps.description: Make sure it is completely wet around all the sides of the sticker alone. Be careful that it isn't the 70% rubbing alcohol variety, as those can be less potent and therefore won't remove as easily.

steps.headline: Rub the wet end of the cotton ball on the edge of one of the sides of the sticker.
steps.description: Rub the sticker until it begins to discolor.

steps.headline: Move the cotton ball down and "coat" this area of the sticker too with the same method above.
Continue until you've reached the bottom section of the sticker, but don't stop rubbing yet.
Take the other end (by now you're wet end has probably turned dry or has lost it's fuzzy end altogether) and dip it into the rubbing alcohol.
steps.description: Repeat the wetting process for this end of the swab/ball.

steps.headline: Move slightly across the sticker until you reach a point where the spot can overlap the edge of your last rubbing area.
Rub the spots onto you've gotten two lines worth of rubbing alcohol applied to the sticker from the cotton ball.
Take your fingernail and begin to pry up the (what should be now) wet sticker.
steps.description: It'll begin to remove. Peel it back slowly and at a slant, working backwards as if to reach the opposite diagonal's corner portion of the sticker.

steps.headline: Reapply and re-work area of the sticker with another wet cotton ball, if it stops becoming detached from that point, or if the sticker doesn't want to remove cleanly from the area.
Clean the area of the sticker, once the sticker has been completely pulled up, with another cotton ball and a little bit more rubbing alcohol.
steps.description: You may still see pieces around the cover where the sticker was where the glue hadn't been completely removed, or where the rubbing alcohol couldn't completely get a full grip far enough through the sticker's inner threads to reach the glue that stickers use. You may even choose to use some cotton swabs to do this portion of the task.

steps.headline: Look at the book, it's sticker should be removed now.

text: Dip a cotton ball in a bottle of 91% rubbing alcohol. Make sure it is completely wet around all the sides of the sticker alone. Be careful that it isn't the 70% rubbing alcohol variety, as those can be less potent and therefore won't remove as easily. Rub the wet end of the cotton ball on the edge of one of the sides of the sticker. Rub the sticker until it begins to discolor. Move the cotton ball down and "coat" this area of the sticker too with the same method above.  Continue until you've reached the bottom section of the sticker, but don't stop rubbing yet.  Take the other end (by now you're wet end has probably turned dry or has lost it's fuzzy end altogether) and dip it into the rubbing alcohol. Repeat the wetting process for this end of the swab/ball. Move slightly across the sticker until you reach a point where the spot can overlap the edge of your last rubbing area.  Rub the spots onto you've gotten two lines worth of rubbing alcohol applied to the sticker from the cotton ball.  Take your fingernail and begin to pry up the (what should be now) wet sticker. It'll begin to remove. Peel it back slowly and at a slant, working backwards as if to reach the opposite diagonal's corner portion of the sticker. Reapply and re-work area of the sticker with another wet cotton ball, if it stops becoming detached from that point, or if the sticker doesn't want to remove cleanly from the area.  Clean the area of the sticker, once the sticker has been completely pulled up, with another cotton ball and a little bit more rubbing alcohol. You may still see pieces around the cover where the sticker was where the glue hadn't been completely removed, or where the rubbing alcohol couldn't completely get a full grip far enough through the sticker's inner threads to reach the glue that stickers use. You may even choose to use some cotton swabs to do this portion of the task. Look at the book, it's sticker should be removed now.
